H0.text: Air is made of molecules of many different gases, and is something we usually can’t see, taste, or smell; we can only feel it when it moves.

H1.text: Light is made of molecules of many different gases, and it is something we usually can’t see, taste, or smell; we can only feel it when it moves.

H2.text: Sound is made of molecules of many different gases, and is something we usually can’t see, taste, or smell; we can only feel it when it moves.

A3.text: the remaining gases are often referred to as trace gases, among which are other greenhouse gases, principally carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, and ozone.

A4.text: Besides argon, other noble gases, neon, helium, krypton, and xenon are also present.

A5.text: The Earth's atmosphere contains many trace gas species that vary significantly depending on nearby sources and sinks.

A6.text: H2S has a characteristic foul odor of rotten eggs and can be smelt in concentrations as low as 0.47 ppb.

A7.text: Wind is the natural movement of air or other gases relative to a planet's surface.
